qas.question: In what year did William IV adopt a purity law pertaining to beer?
What was the title of William IV in 1516?
What was the name of the purity law that regulated beer in 1516, and is still in use today?

plausible_answers.text: more control of the process and greater knowledge of the results.

qas.question: The development of thermometers was the main factor that changed brewing by allowing what?

What is the oldest food-quality law in use in the 19th century?

plausible_answers.text: brewing by allowing the brewer more control of the process and greater knowledge of the results

qas.question: What did the development of hyrdrothermometers change?

context: In <a0_0>1516<a0_0/>, <a4_0>William IV<a4_0/>, <a1_0>Duke of Bavaria<a1_0/>, adopted <b9_0><b10_0><b11_0>the <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0><b8_0>Reinheitsgebot<b10_0/><b9_0/><b8_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> (purity law)<b11_0/><b5_0/>, perhaps the oldest food-quality regulation still in use in the 21st century, according to which the only allowed ingredients of beer are water, hops and <a3_0>barley-malt<a3_0/>. Beer produced before the Industrial Revolution continued to be made and sold on a domestic scale, although by the 7th century AD, beer was also being produced and sold by European monasteries. During the Industrial Revolution, the production of beer moved from artisanal manufacture to industrial manufacture, and domestic manufacture ceased to be significant by the end of the 19th century. The development of hydrometers and thermometers changed <b12_0>brewing by allowing the brewer <b7_0>more control of the process and greater knowledge of the results<b12_0/>.
